title: Supreme Court Weighs Breadth of Computer Hacking Law
sub_head: Officer allegedly used law-enforcement database for personal purposes in a case that has drawn widespread attention
body:
WASHINGTON—When a Georgia police officer ran a license plate check in 2015 for an acquaintance who paid him for the favor, he received a felony conviction—and set the stage for a hotly debated Supreme Court case about the sweep of federal law on computer hacking.
The high court took up the officer’s appeal on Monday to examine a thorny question about the decades-old Computer Fraud and Abuse Act: Breaking into a computer system is a clear violation, but what about when someone has legal access to a computer or database but...
